title: 105_s896
content: The "Landmine Elimination Act of 1997" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congress findings include a Senate vote on a moratorium on anti-personnel landmines, retired military officers urging a ban on landmines, and the impact of landmines in Vietnam on US military personnel. The generals support a ban on landmines for humanitarian and military reasons, citing the impact on US military personnel in Vietnam and soldiers in Bosnia. The Department of State highlights the frequency of landmine casualties, and President Clinton commits to pursuing an international ban on anti-personnel landmines. The Department of State reports that a person is killed or injured by a landmine every 22 minutes. President Clinton and various international organizations declare goals to establish landmine-free zones. Canada announces negotiations for a treaty banning anti-personnel landmines. African Unity adopted the goal of establishing Africa as an anti-personnel landmine free zone. Canada announced negotiations for a treaty banning anti-personnel landmines to be completed in Ottawa in December 1997. The United Nations General Assembly passed a resolution to pursue a treaty banning the use, stockpiling, production, and transfer of anti-personnel landmines. Formal negotiations on the Ottawa treaty are set to begin in Oslo, Norway in September 1997. The United States could secure broad support for a legally binding agreement by exerting its international influence. Formal negotiations for the Ottawa treaty to ban anti-personnel landmines will begin in Oslo, Norway in September 1997. The United States could use its international influence to secure broad support for a binding treaty, which would enhance US security and humanitarian interests by deterring the use of landmines against US Armed Forces and civilians. SEC. 3. RESTRICTION ON NEW DEPLOYMENTS OF ANTI-PERSONNEL LANDMINES. Beginning on January 1, 2000, no funds may be used for new deployments of anti-personnel landmines. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report within 180 days outlining alternatives for such deployments on the Korean Peninsula. The President can delay the restriction if certifying reports are submitted annually to Congress. The President can delay the restriction on new deployments of anti-personnel landmines on the Korean Peninsula if annual reports are submitted to Congress certifying the necessity for such deployments in defense of the Republic of Korea. The reports must include efforts to implement proposed alternatives and any subsequent proposals by the Secretary of Defense and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "anti-personnel landmine" refers to munitions designed to detonate by proximity to a person, excluding command-detonated Claymore munitions. "New deployments of anti-personnel landmines" are those placed after January 1, 2000.
